Introduction

Vascular rings are rare, congenital malformations of the aortic arch that encircle and compress the trachea, esophagus, or both.  Affected children exhibit respiratory and/or feeding symptoms that overlap with more common childhood conditions, often leading to delays in diagnosis.

Pathogenesis



During embryogenesis, the aortic arch is formed from 6 paired aortic arches and the right and left dorsal aortae (

figure 1
).  Normal left aortic arch formation occurs through the specific regression of certain segments (eg, right dorsal aorta) and remodeling of others.  Vascular rings occur when certain embryonic arch segments abnormally persist, forming vascular structures that encircle the trachea and esophagus.



A double aortic arch, although rare, is the most frequently observed vascular ring anomaly and arises due to failed regression of the right dorsal aorta (

figure 2
).  Less common configurations of vascular rings include an aberrant left or right subclavian artery.  Vascular malformations that do not fully encircle the trachea or esophagus are not considered true vascular rings and are often asymptomatic and discovered incidentally.



Although there are no known modifiable risk factors for vascular rings, there is an increased incidence with certain congenital conditions, including 22q11.2 deletion syndromes.  In addition, many children with vascular rings have associated cardiac defects, such as ventricular septal defect, tetralogy of Fallot, or aortic coarctation.

Clinical presentation



Because the degree of tracheal and esophageal compression varies, severe cases may present as life-threatening airway obstruction in a neonate, whereas mild cases may be asymptomatic and found incidentally in an adult.



The most common and classic presentation is in an infant with a reported history of "noisy breathing" since birth and tracheal or esophageal compression.

Tracheal compression



  • Biphasic stridor that improves with neck extension (which reduces tracheal compression).
  • Dyspnea associated with crying or feeding (due to increased airflow and turbulence through a narrowed airway).
  • Wheezing unresponsive to bronchodilators (because smooth muscle relaxation does not affect the external compression of the airway).
  • Chronic cough and recurrent respiratory tract infections (due to disruption of normal mucociliary clearance).

Esophageal compression



  • Feeding difficulties, such as choking with feeds, prolonged feeding time, and feeding aversion (due to ineffective peristalsis and poor expansion).
  • Solid-food dysphagia and food impaction (due to ineffective peristalsis & poor expansion).
  • Vomiting.


Poor weight gain can result from increased work of breathing and feeding difficulties, particularly after solid food is introduced.

Evaluation



Evaluation for infants with chronic respiratory symptoms (eg, stridor) typically begins with a chest x-ray to evaluate for common respiratory pathologies (eg, pneumonia).  In patients with a vascular ring, lateral x-ray may reveal anterior bowing of the trachea.



For those with primarily gastrointestinal symptoms (eg, dysphagia), a fluoroscopic swallowing study often demonstrates a posterior esophageal indentation.

Diagnosis



The definitive diagnosis of a vascular ring is made using CT or MR angiography of the chest, which delineates the specific anatomic structures forming the vascular ring.  Because a vascular ring is a congenital vascular defect, echocardiography is also performed to evaluate for associated intracardiac anomalies (eg, ventricular septal defect).



Prenatal echocardiography may also provide a definitive diagnosis in some cases.

Differential diagnosis



The most common respiratory and gastrointestinal symptoms seen in children with a vascular ring are stridor and dysphagia, respectively.  It is important to differentiate a vascular ring from other conditions with overlapping symptoms.

Stridor



  • Croup (
    figure 3
    ):  Viral infection and inflammation of the larynx and subglottic airway result in inspiratory stridor, barking cough, and hoarseness; biphasic stridor can be seen in severe cases.  The presentation is acute, gastrointestinal symptoms are not seen, and x-ray reveals subglottic narrowing.
  • Laryngomalacia (
    figure 4
    ):  Decreased supraglottic airway tone causes laryngomalacia, the most common cause of chronic stridor in infancy.  The stridor is inspiratory and improves with prone positioning.
  • Airway hemangioma:  Rapid proliferation of a vascular airway lesion in the first 1-2 months of life can lead to progressively worsening biphasic stridor.  Because this narrowing is intrinsic (rather than caused by external compression), the stridor does not generally improve with neck extension.  In addition, cutaneous hemangiomas of the chin/neck are often present (
    image 1
    ).
  • Foreign body aspiration:  Biphasic stridor can occur if a foreign body is lodged in the trachea.  This condition typically presents with acute symptoms after a choking event, and improvement of stridor with neck extension would not be expected.

Dysphagia



  • Gastroesophageal reflux disease (
    figure 5
    ):  Chronic passage of gastric contents into the esophagus can result in esophagitis.  Affected infants are often irritable and may have poor weight gain and feeding difficulties, including dysphagia in severe cases.  Stridor is not an associated finding, and symptoms often improve with acid-suppressing medications.
  • Tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF)
    (figure 6
    ):  Esophageal atresia with a distal TEF is the most common type of TEF.  Newborns are symptomatic immediately after birth with excessive secretions, choking, and an inability to feed.  Biphasic stridor is not a typical feature.
  • Eosinophilic esophagitis:  This condition is characterized by esophageal dysfunction and localized eosinophil-predominant inflammation.  Symptoms may include food impaction and dysphagia.  It is typically considered in older children with a history of allergies, asthma, or atopy.  Dyspnea is not expected.
  • Achalasia (
    figure 7
    ):  Degeneration of ganglion cells in the esophageal wall can cause an inability for the lower esophageal sphincter to relax.  Dysphagia and regurgitation of food are common.  An onset before adolescence is extremely rare.

Management and prognosis



Definitive treatment is the surgical division of the structures that create the vascular ring.  The prognosis is excellent for most children, with complete resolution of symptoms after surgery.

Summary



Vascular rings (

) are congenital anomalies that can cause tracheoesophageal compression.  They should be suspected in infants and children with otherwise unexplained chronic stridor and feeding difficulties.  Chest x-ray findings typically include tracheal indentation, and diagnosis is made using CT or MR angiography of the chest.  Treatment is a surgical division of the vascular ring, and postoperative long-term outcomes are generally excellent.
